nytimes_articles.headline: True to Style, Mayor Tells Boston He Will Get His Way as Envoy to Vatican
nytimes_articles.abstract: People here have been telling Ray Flynn stories since the popular, populist Mayor announced at a tearful news conference outside his Gate of Heaven church in March that he would leave by early July to become Ambassador to the Vatican.    But now the latest one, already being proclaimed a Ray Flynn classic, is unfolding: the former Providence College basketball star goes one on one with the State Department over his job description, and wins.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Knick Fine for Oakley?
nytimes_articles.abstract: After complaining publicly about his playing time, his contract and his role, power forward Charles Oakley met yesterday with Dave Checketts, the Knicks' president. While Checketts would not say if any disciplinary action would be taken against Oakley for speaking out before speaking with him, a fine is probably forthcoming for the Knicks' co-captain.   "This is the second time Charles has done something like this," said Checketts, referring to an incident last season when Oakley said the Knicks made a mistake by failing to keep Xavier McDaniel. "It's almost like Charles is a volcano waiting to erupt. It's O.K. to be frustrated after a season, but this is not the way to handle it. Discussions like that should be kept inside. I'm disappointed, but we'll deal with it."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: One solution is to arm the Croats and Bosnians, and intervene actively against the Serbs with NATO air power. .The other, certainly safer and more humane in the short term, would be to acknowledge openly the inevitability of Greater Serbia (with all du

nytimes_articles.headline: Vichy Aide Accused of War Crimes Is Slain in France
nytimes_articles.abstract: A prominent official in France's collaborationist Vichy government who was facing charges of crimes against humanity for deporting Jews to Nazi death camps during World War II was shot dead by a lone gunman at his home here early today.   A few hours later, a 49-year-old frustrated author, Christian Didier, was charged with murder in the death of Rene Bousquet, 84. Before his arrest, Mr. Didier summoned television reporters to a suburban hotel and recounted in detail how he had fired four bullets at the man he described as "that piece of garbage."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pop Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Beck on Track   Jeff Beck, one of rock's most influential guitarists, is traveling along new byways and retracing old ones.   Later this month, Epic will release "Crazy Legs," an album that brings Mr. Beck together with a British roots-rock band, the Big Town Playboys, in a collection of classics originally performed by the 1950's rocker Gene Vincent and his band the Blue Caps. The album, a tribute to the Blue Caps' original lead guitarist, Cliff Gallup, features Mr. Beck playing what he says he was struggling to learn to play when he was 15 years old.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Bad Malpractice Idea
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The Clinton Administration's proposal to shift the malpractice burden from physicians to insurance companies (front page, May 21) is 180 degrees off course. At first glance, from the physician's point of view, it seems a good idea; however, in the long run it would not reduce the cost of health care, but probably increase it.   It has been shown time after time that a trusting and close relationship between physician and patient prevents a lawsuit if a complication or problem arises. When complaints are addressed to a faceless, large corporation with deep pockets, there will be no personal ties to prevent or moderate lawsuits. Also, corporations do not settle claims quickly; but seem always to be involved in drawn-out and costly proceedings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Simmons in Hospital With Chest Pains
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Pirates' general manager, TED SIMMONS, was admitted to St. Francis General Hospital in Pittsburgh yesterday with chest pains and was in stable condition. Simmons, 43, had a series of tests after being admitted, according to a short statement issued by the Pirates. He is expected to remain hospitalized for the next several days.   A Pirates spokesman, JIM TRDINICH, said that after developing the pain, Simmons consulted with Trainer KENT BIGGERSTAFF before being admitted to the hospital.

nytimes_articles.headline: Behind Dinkins Budget: Recovering From Gamble
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the end, the election-year budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins hoped would demonstrate his managerial mettle came a year too soon.   The staffs of the Mayor and the City Council were still working last night, five days into their final round of negotiations, trying to resolve the last details of the city's spending plan for the fiscal year starting next month. But the budget's thrust is clear: it will feature about $300 million in spending cuts and a retrenchment in some services not likely to endear Mr. Dinkins and other political leaders with voters this fall.

nytimes_articles.headline: L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L!
nytimes_articles.abstract: A start might bring an end. That was the theory, anyway, concerning Anthony Young and his 19 straight defeats.   "Put his destiny in his hands," Manager Dallas Green had said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Night of Turning Points
nytimes_articles.abstract: Getting there, and being there, are two distinctly different things. In Foxboro Stadium in the suburbs of Boston on Wednesday, the U.S. national team plays England in a rehearsal for a World Cup to which neither has earned the right to participate next s

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a time when all attention is focused on the Muslims, I would like to speak on behalf of those Serbs from Bosnia whose plight and suffering the media have chosen to ignore. Are the names of Podravanje, Orahovici, Osredak, Brezani, Turija or Gloadi fami

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: By arming the Muslims we risk an arms race on all sides and the perpetuation of the war. But we must then defend those to whom we refuse self-defense.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Does anyone seriously believe that the European powers would not intervene in ex-Yugoslavia if Bosnian Muslims were implicated in the "ethnic cleansing" of Croatian Catholics? Does anyone seriously believe that America would not intervene in Bo

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Panel Backs Military Spending the Pentagon Never Sought
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Senate committee followed the House today in approving $1.2 billion in military spending that the Pentagon had not asked for.   With no extended argument or questioning, the Appropriations Committee sent to the Senate floor a measure that also includes $400 million of the $19.3 billion in economic-stimulus spending President Clinton asked for last winter.

nytimes_articles.headline: Princeton President Addresses Graduates
nytimes_articles.abstract: Princeton University conferred 1,075 undergraduate and 611 advanced degrees yesterday at its 246th commencement held on the lawn in front of Nassau Hall in Princeton, N.J.   The valedictory was delivered by Niles A. Pierce, a mechanical and aerospace engineering major. D. Graham Burnett, a history major, was the salutatorian, delivering his speech in Latin as Princeton tradition requires.

nytimes_articles.headline: Like It or Not, We Must Lead
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff caused an uproar recently when he said the United States was withdrawing from its role as international leader.

The chief problem with American foreign policy, however, is not what he said but what the Clinton Administration has not said.

Unlike cold war Administrations, whose central international goal -- the containment of the Soviet Union -- was fixed, the Clinton Administration must devise and present its own vision of American purposes in the world. It has not done so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kentucky Extends Pitino's Contract
nytimes_articles.abstract: RICK PITINO's contract extension calls for him to remain as head basketball coach at the University of Kentucky into the next century. The school announced yesterday that Pitino's contract was extended through the 1999-2000 season.   "I think he made a career decision, that he wants to be a college coach, and he wants to be a college coach at Kentucky," the Kentucky athletic director, C.M. NEWTON said after a meeting of the Kentucky Athletics Association's board of directors in Lexington.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: There are two major single knockout team championships in New York City, the Grand National and the Reisinger, and one player has a remarkable streak in progress. A year ago, George Tornay of Manhattan won the Grand National Swiss teams plus the subsequent knockout and was a runner-up in the Reisinger. This year he again won the Grand National Swiss, was a winner Sunday in the Reisinger, and later this month will compete in the final of the Grand National knockout. John Roberts and August Boehm also won five of the six events but were derailed in the sixth by external circumstances and had to withdraw. Stay tuned for next year to see if the streak will continue.   On the diagramed deal from the Reisinger semifinal Tornay held the South cards. He had a difficult rebid after opening one diamond and hearing a one-spade response, and made a slightly eccentric rebid. He chose three no-trump, which is normally based on stoppers in the unbid suits, which he had, and a long solid suit, which he did not have.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mourning Hero Who Transcended Sports World
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fans gathered in front of the coffee bar co-owned by the New Jersey Nets star Drazen Petrovic to pay tribute today to the basketball player and national hero of this war-torn country who died in a car accident Monday in Germany.   A mound of freshly lighted candles outside Cafe Amadeus illuminated scores of crying faces as people sat in silence in front of pictures of Petrovic, whom many regarded proudly as a symbol of this newly-independent republic's nationhood.

nytimes_articles.headline: Graf and Agassi Uncertain for Wimbledon
nytimes_articles.abstract: With Wimbledon set to start in less than two weeks, STEFFI GRAF and ANDRE AGASSI are nursing injuries that might keep them from defending their titles.   Graf, who won the French Open on Saturday, was then treated at a hospital in Essen, Germany, for an injury suffered during her quarterfinal match, last Wednesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Angelenos Vote A Conservative As New Mayor
nytimes_articles.abstract: Richard Riordan, a conservative businessman, was elected Mayor of Los Angeles tonight, ushering in a new political era after the 20-year leadership of Tom Bradley and his coalition of blacks and white liberals.   Mr. Riordan, 62, defeated Michael Woo, a liberal City Councilman, in a hard-fought, nonpartisan race in which personal attacks drowned out serious debate over the future of this city as it struggles with its evolving multi-ethnic identity and with the aftermath of last year's riots.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Orders The Release Of Haitians
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal judge ordered yesterday that all Haitians held in a detention camp at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base be released and that the camp -- opened two years ago in an effort to stem a flood of Haitian immigrants -- be closed immediately.   Unless the Clinton Administration files an appeal, the ruling by Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. in the United States District Court in Brooklyn will close a painful chapter in America's immigration history.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The West must deploy adequate NATO forces in Macedonia, Kosovo and perhaps Albania before open warfare engulfs these countries too.

nytimes_articles.headline: Haiti's Premier Quits After Four Ministers Refuse to Step Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prime Minister Marc Bazin resigned today, saying that the refusal of four ministers to step down after their dismissal had made governing impossible.   Mr. Bazin, appointed by the ruling military nine months after the coup that overthrew the the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, said the actions of the four ministers gave him no choice.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: No Spy Exchange : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON - The State Department has given a refusal to Germany's demand to have the leading German spy, Rintelen, freed in exchange of Siegfried London, represented as a United States citizen and detained in Germany on a charge of espionage. Germany had

nytimes_articles.headline: Stephen Fry Goes West And Adopts New Look: Jeeves in Cowboy Boots
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stephen Fry has sampled the American West and pronounced it good. The British actor, best known to American audiences as Jeeves on "Masterpiece Theater" and as the title character in the recent film "Peter's Friends," has the Texas twang down pat, and during a recent interview in New York he paced his hotel room wearing a new pair of snakeskin cowboy boots. The accent and the boots were souvenirs of his stay in Texas for a guest role as Oscar Wilde on "Ned Blessing," a nouvelle Western series that CBS plans to introduce in the fall.   Mr. Fry has fond memories of the shoot, which took place near Austin on an authentic-looking Old West set. "I was actually able to say, after lunch, 'Well, I guess I'll mosey down to the corral,' " he said. "And I did, literally, mosey down to the corral."

nytimes_articles.headline: TENSION GROWING IN SOMALI CAPITAL
nytimes_articles.abstract: In anticipation of United Nations military action against Somali armed factions, the exodus of aid workers continued today, and the tension wound tighter with at least five gunfights and sniper attacks reported between Somalis and peacekeepers.   There was also a sense of dread among the Somalis today, and many said they were sending women and children out of the city.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Holocaust was genocide on a scale never before seen. The slightest comparison to the civil war in Yugoslavia represents a total lack of perspective.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Los Angeles Mayor Chosen   Richard Riordan, a conservative businessman, defeated City Councilman Michael Woo, despite a Clinton endorsement. Page A14. Diplomatic Logjam Broken    Officials say Walter F. Mondale will be Ambassador to Japan, while Richard C. Holbrooke, a Carter Administration aide, will go to Germany and Stephen J. Solarz to India. Page A12. Alabama's School Challenge    Alabama is grappling with a judge's ruling that its public schools violate state law by failing to provide an adequate education. Page B7. More Access to Cable Shows    After an antitrust inquiry, seven cable TV companies are to make shows more available to rivals. Page D1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Weicker Signs Bill to Forbid Assault Rifles
nytimes_articles.abstract: Connecticut, long a center of gun manufacturing, tonight became the third state, after New Jersey and California, to ban the sale of semiautomatic military-style assault rifles, including the Colt Sporter, a gun made here in Hartford.   The State Senate passed the landmark measure as an 18-to-18 tie was broken by Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark at 8:30 P.M. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. signed it into law an hour and a half later at a brief ceremony with the bill's bipartisan supporters. The law forbids the sale of a category of arms that the police say is turning up in greater numbers in the hands of urban drug gangs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Immigrants Both Renew and Unsettle Chinatown
nytimes_articles.abstract: The elderly man, influential and well known in Chinatown, stood in the front room of his office on Mott Street and hovered between the desire for full disclosure and the need for discretion.   He talked about illegal immigrants, like the ones who came ashore in Queens on Sunday morning. He worried that they faced years of misery and hardship here, that they would contribute to a loss of control in the community, a lessening of the influence of the old guard. Some of them, he said, would inevitably be tempted by gang membership, already a growing problem in Chinatown.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mother Nature's Pesticide Factory
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In the environmentalists' war against technology, nowhere are the stakes higher than the assault on pesticides. The current battleground is the Delaney Clause of the Food Additives Amendment of 1958, which bans anything that causes cancer in humans or rodents from being added to processed food. 

The new Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner, in February asked Congress to review the clause, calling it an anachronism that threatened the U.S. food supply. Environmentalists objected loudly, and the E.P.A. quickly retracted her remarks. But Ms. Browner was right: this outdated law should be changed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toward a Lasting Solution : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I do not know how the Bosnia mess can be cleared up. But I do know that you cannot clear up a mess by making a bigger mess.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Of Skinheads High on Hate And Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Romper Stomper," Geoffrey Wright's viscerally supercharged film about neo-Nazi skinheads in Melbourne, Australia, is a film that runs on the adrenaline of hate. From its harrowing opening scene, in which a gang of skinheads terrorizes a group of Vietnamese immigrants, through a prolonged sequence in which the Vietnamese strike back at their tormentors, the film exults at being in the thick of action that is often savagely and sadistically violent.    This being Australia, not the United States, the violence is done with fist, boot, baseball bat and tire chain; not with firearms. But the absence of high-efficiency technological splatter doesn't make it any less bloody or intense.

nytimes_articles.headline: Death Throws A Pall Over The Title Talk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Before a ball could be dribbled, a point scored, a game completed or a championship won, the Chicago Bulls and the Phoenix Suns were sadly forced to put their battle for the National Basketball Association title into a different place today because of the death of Drazen Petrovic of the Nets.    With Game 1 of the N.B.A. championship series on Wednesday night, there was the usual talk of maneuvers and matchups, but mortality seemed foremost on everyone's mind.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toward a Lasting Solution : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations should acquire its own standing military force. Instead of today's peacekeepers working under strict noncombat and zero-casualty rules, the UN force would recruit individual volunteers whose nationality would be irrelevant, for no poli

nytimes_articles.headline: H.I.V. Immunity Discussed at Berlin Conference
nytimes_articles.abstract: A small number of prostitutes in Nairobi, Kenya, appear to have avoided infection with the virus that causes AIDS despite frequent unprotected sex with infected men, researchers said at an international AIDS meeting here today.   The women are of intense scientific interest to researchers, who believe that clues to why they fought off the virus, H.I.V., could lead to the development of vaccines and other therapies.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kelly Has Cure for What Ails Yankees
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Yankees were slipping and sliding on their road trip, turning Buck Showalter's face redder, playing listlessly and ready to plummet in the standings. Their slump stood at three losses in four games, but it felt worse. Much worse.   So on this night when the Yankees needed Jimmy Key to be a stopper and resuscitate a stumbling team, what was Showalter to think when his ace had his shortest outing of the year and was finished before the seventh inning? How much redder could his face get?

nytimes_articles.headline: Diversity on the Supreme Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: In drifting toward the choice of Bruce Babbitt as his nominee for the Supreme Court seat being vacated by Justice Byron White, President Clinton is squandering an opportunity to enhance the diversity of the nation's highest court.   Mr. Clinton seeks high court candidates who are "supremely qualified," the main quality his press secretary stressed yesterday. He seeks someone with "keen intellect, good judgment, experience both with the law and with the lives of everyday people . . . and a big heart."

nytimes_articles.headline: CROATIAN FORCES FACE MUSLIM ARMY
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hundreds of Croatian civilians streamed out of Travnik, in central Bosnia, today in automobiles, tractors, carts and bicycles as Croatian militiamen fighting Bosnian Government forces shelled the picturesque town that was Bosnia's capital in the Ottoman era.   Mate Boban, leader of the Bosnian Croats, accused the Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces of executing Croatian prisoners in Travnik, but there was no independent confirmation of the allegation, which was reported today in Croatian newspapers.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Television Listings For NBA's Title Series
nytimes_articles.abstract: The National Basketball Association's championship series, which is being telecast worldwide, will be shown by the Eurosport cable network on the Continent and by the U.S. sports cable network ESPN International in Southeast Asia, the Pacific Rim and Lat

nytimes_articles.headline: Whitman Wins Republican Vote To Take On Florio in New Jersey
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christine Todd Whitman, who nearly went to the United States Senate three years ago on a tide of anger against New Jersey's Governor, Jim Florio, tonight won the right to try to unseat Mr. Florio herself.   Mrs. Whitman, 46, soundly defeated two vastly more experienced rivals to win the Republican primary. In doing so, she became the first woman in New Jersey to win a major party's gubernatorial nomination.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   BOSTON RED SOX -- Signed Kurtiss Bogott and James Fernandes, pitchers; Joseph Hayward, outfielder, and Gregory Patton and Nathan Tebbs, infielders.   MINNESOTA TWINS -- Optioned Pat Mahomes, pitcher, to Portland of the Pacific Coast League. Purchased the contract of Eddie Guardado, pitcher, from Nashville of the Southern League. Signed Aaron Santini, shortstop and Deron Dowhower, pitcher.

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Race John Houseman Theater 450 West 42d Street Clinton Written and performed by Paul Mooney; lighting by Robert Bessoir; production coordinator, E. F. Morrill; sound by Charles McIntyre; general manager, Paul Morer. Presented by Eric Krebs.   The most acute point that the comedian Paul Mooney drives home in his funny and very profane one-man show, "Race," is how a white person's cultural nostalgia can easily be a black person's nightmare. Commenting on a recent movie adaptation of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," he excoriates the film makers for choosing to romanticize a time when black people like himself were in chains.

nytimes_articles.headline: Behind Immigrants' Voyage, Long Reach of Chinese Gang
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Chinese gang that recently emerged as a major force in the smuggling of illegal immigrants helped organize the voyage of the tramp steamer that ran aground off Queens on Sunday with nearly 300 Chinese immigrants aboard, law-enforcement officials believe.   Federal officials said they had evidence that one organizer of the smuggling enterprise was Guo Liang Chi, also known as Ah Kay, the 28-year-old leader of the Fuk Ching gang. Both Federal and New York officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, believe that members of the gang were to have unloaded the illegal immigrants and to have collected $30,000 from each of them for the 17,000-mile journey from the Far East.

nytimes_articles.headline: Canadiens Find LeClair's Value Is Rising as Season Winds Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: In each of the last two games, John LeClair has scored the winning goal in overtime for the Montreal Canadiens. Both times, his coach, Jacques Demers, has sat next to LeClair in the post-game news conference and declared, "John LeClair is going to be a rich man."   Because LeClair is making a modest $225,000 as he heads into the option year of his contract, Serge Savard was asked for his views on the subject. Savard, the general manager of the Canadiens, is the man who negotiates salaries with the players.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK CITY GANG SUSPECTED IN IMMIGRANT SMUGGLING   Law-enforcement officials say they believe a Chinese gang, which has recently emerged as a major force in the growing world of illegal-immigrant smuggling, helped organize the ill-starred voyage of the tramp steamer that ran aground off Queens on Sunday with nearly 300 Chinese men and women aboard. A1. CONNECTICUT GUN BAN IS APPROVED   A bill banning assault-type weapons has been passed by the Connecticut General Assembly after a series of close votes in Hartford and has been signed by the Governor. A1.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-13  COLD WAR OVER, ILLEGAL SEX UP  Since the end of the cold war, criminal organizations have set up networks to bring young women from the former Soviet bloc into the sex industry of Western Europe, police officials in Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany say.  A1  VICHY OFFICIAL ASSASSINATED  An official in the Vichy Government in France, facing charges for deporting Jews to Nazi death camps, was shot dead in his Paris home. A 49-year-old frustrated author was charged with murder. A3

nytimes_articles.headline: For Donald, A New Chance at Open
nytimes_articles.abstract: His second-place finish in the United States Open three years ago was not enough for a free ticket to this year's tournament. So Mike Donald had to battle 141 other candidates today for 31 spots in next week's extravaganza at Baltusrol in Springfield, N.J.   The field, which included 52 PGA Tour players and six amateurs, played one round at Old Oaks Country Club and another down the road at Century Country Club. When it was all over, Donald was the top qualifier, shooting a three-under-par 67 at the 6,503-yard Old Oaks and a three-under 68 at the 6,809-yard Century for low medalist honors at six-under 135.

nytimes_articles.headline: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Newark Boys and Girls 
 Paul Azinger won the Memorial in Ohio on Sunday and Jane Geddes the Oldsmobille Classic in Michigan, but on Monday morning they joined John Daly, Fuzzy Zoeller, Chi Chi Rodriguez, Pat Bradley, Danielle Ammaccapane and Cindy Rarick in a benefit for the Boys and Girls Clubs of Newark, which serves 5,000 young people from ages 6 to 18.

The Somerset Hills Country Club in Bernardsville provided the setting for the benefit, where 32 amateurs paid $8,500 each to play with the stars and a limited number of spectators paid $300 each to watch.

nytimes_articles.headline: Disabled and Chronically Ill Gain Health Coverage and Jobs Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission declared today that employers may not refuse to hire people with disabilities because of concern about their effect on health insurance costs. It also said that disabled workers must generally be given "equal access" to any health insurance provided to other employees.   At a meeting this afternoon, the Federal agency adopted a broad policy statement explaining how it intended to enforce a 1990 law, the Americans with Disabilities Act, to curb discrimination by employers and insurers providing health benefits.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption last Wednesday with an interview with John Cardinal O'Connor misstated the scene of the interview. It was at the Catholic Center, 1011 First Avenue.

nytimes_articles.headline: Washington Talk; White House Offices: Matter of Inches
nytimes_articles.abstract: When President Clinton announced that David R. Gergen would be brought into the White House as a new and important adviser, all the signs of a classic Washington power play were evident. Except one. Mr. Gergen has no office.   Mr. Gergen, who has worked at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue before and knows well the value of its internal real estate, has been temporarily relegated to a basement office with one assistant that he brought with him.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: What is the difference between a "safe haven" and a ghetto?

nytimes_articles.headline: Large, Happy Crowds Greeted Opening of West Harlem Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A report of the opening of Riverbank State Park May 27 concentrated on issues other than the park story (news article, May 28).   About 20,000 people of all ages and physical capabilities from all parts of the city and beyond happily streamed into the park to celebrate and enjoy a 28-acre half-mile waterfront park that offers indoor and outdoor recreational and cultural experiences.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The trial of two Serbs convicted of committing war crimes in Bosnia appears to have been a propaganda spectacle. They were tried by the Muslim-led Bosnian government solely on the basis of their self-incriminating testimony. It is highly probable that th

nytimes_articles.headline: Georgia Tech Leader Is Player of the Year
nytimes_articles.abstract: DAVID DUVAL of Georgia Tech, the runner-up in the last two National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championships, was named player of the year yesterday by the Golf Coaches Association. The senior from Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., will receive the Jack Nicklaus Award. Duval is only the third collegiate golfer to earn first-team all-America honors four consecutive years. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Why Shouldn't a Woman Be a Princess?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I take issue with Ann Quindlen's "Happily Ever" column, calling Masako Owada of Japan a "sacrificial lamb" for choosing to marry Crown Prince Naruhito. Ms. Quindlen pits one woman's personal choice to marry against a feminist philosophical ideal of how an intelligent and well-educated woman should live. It seems to me that by Ms. Quindlen's argument a woman who does not pursue a high-powered career is to be pitied and blackballed from the feminist clique for not living up to her potential.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yugoslavia is in the heart of Europe. Unfortunately, Europe has neither heart, brains nor guts.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Malawi Dictator, Time Will Soon Run Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your May 29 and June 1 articles on Malawi succintly describe the political pressure cooker that Malawi is today. But you fail to underline the most serious denials of basic human rights that Life President Hastings Kenneth Banda inflicts on the Malawian people. The opposition leader, Chakufwa Chihana, remains in jail, unwell and cruelly punished for the "crime" of believing in democracy.

nytimes_articles.headline: School Boards In New Jersey Face Scrutiny
nytimes_articles.abstract: With $12 billion in annual spending and jobs for 110,000 people, local schools are big business here as in so many states. Those numbers add up to a lot of potential for conflicts of interest.   That's where a new nine-member School Ethics Commission comes in: to shine the light of public scrutiny on patronage and corruption on school boards in New Jersey, where the state Education Department has taken over operation of the Paterson and Jersey City schools. It has intervened in the business operations of the Newark and Trenton districts.

nytimes_articles.headline: New York City Sees Decline In Math Scores
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City public school students performed at about the national average on a new mathematics achievement test given for the first time this year, and testing experts said yesterday that the results cast doubt on school officials' claims of sharp improvement in student performance.   In recent years, citywide student performance on the annual mathematics achievement tests has gradually moved upward; on last year's test, 6 of 10 students performed at or above the national average. The administration of Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has pointed to those numbers as a validation of its efforts to improve students' basic skills.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: We shall be shamed by our grandchildren's judgment that we knowingly permitted starvation, torture, rape and "ethnic cleansing" to go on so long.

nytimes_articles.headline: Personal Health
nytimes_articles.abstract: MANY factors can touch off an asthmatic attack in people prone to this frightening constriction of the airways: pollens, dust, cigarette smoke and even cold air. But one of the most distressing and most often unrecognized triggers is vigorous physical exercise.   Exercise-induced asthma is extremely common, affecting more than 80 percent of people with ordinary asthma, 30 to 40 percent of those with allergic rhinitis ("hay fever") and 9 percent of people without asthma or allergies, who develop asthmatic symptoms only when they exercise.

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Classified  Union Square Upstairs 100 East 17th Street Manhattan Written and performed by Fred Adler; co-written by Dan Cedeno; directed by William Oliver; set by Bernie Honigman; lighting by Michele Disco; costumes by Sama Meschel. Presented by WonderWorks Unlimited.    As satirists go, Fred Adler is like a puppy: young, frisky and eager to please. These characteristics are on display at the Union Square Upstairs Theater, where Mr. Adler is appearing in his one-man show, "Classified," Thursdays through Sundays until June 27.

nytimes_articles.headline: Presbyterians Vote To Keep Prohibition Against Gay Pastors
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a session marked by revealing personal testimony and raucous disruption, the 2.8 million-member Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted Monday to maintain the church's position barring sexually active, declared homosexuals from ordination or appointment as pastors.    The church's General Assembly softened the action by calling on local congregations to participate in a three-year churchwide discussion of homosexuality and its relevance to church membership and ministry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toward a Lasting Solution : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: A permanent solution to the Yugoslav problem must be found, otherwise other nations will inevitably be drawn into this deadly vortex. .Given that longstanding frontiers should not be changed, nor can they bar war, there is only one possible solution: c

nytimes_articles.headline: Khmer Rouge Seek Coalition Post
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Khmer Rouge, which boycotted elections in Cambodia last month and threatened to sabotage the balloting with violence, seem to have had a change of heart since the final votes were cast.   The Maoist-inspired rebels are not only willing to accept the results, they are now also maneuvering to join whatever government is formed.

nytimes_articles.headline: New York's Needless Budget Quarrels
nytimes_articles.abstract: Forced to cut more from New York City's budget, the Mayor and City Council are still squabbling, deadlocked over the shape of $300 million in cuts and two difficult initiatives. There are solutions to both if Council Speaker Peter Vallone means what he says and really wants to cooperate with Mayor David Dinkins rather than use the budget to win political battles.   Medical care for the poor. With New York desperately short of primary care facilities for poor families, the Dinkins administration wisely proposes to create at least 30 health clinics. But the Council is holding the plan hostage to a turf war over who controls the money.

nytimes_articles.headline: Santa Fe Portrait; A Longtime Pillar of the Government Now Aids Those Hurt by Its Bombs
nytimes_articles.abstract: East of the Nevada Test Site, where the Government conducted atmospheric tests of atomic bombs, the town of Alamo, Nev., rises in the desert. In August 1978, at the urging of a cousin, Stewart L. Udall went to Alamo and listened to mothers tell of the dust and radiation from the blasts that settled over the town in the 1950's and of the children they had lost to leukemia.   "Until then, there were a lot of people in that country who suspected a link, but they kept it to themselves," said Mr. Udall, who once was Secretary of the Interior for Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. "They had been fed a steady diet of lies by the Government that there was no danger. That was my first trip to investigate, and I felt there was more to it, that it would be difficult and that we would be breaking new ground."

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Extended Forecast  La Mama E.T.C. 74A East Fourth Street East Village By Franz Xaver Kroetz; translated by Erica Bilder and Estelle Parsons; directed by Ms. Bilder; assistant director, Stephen Nunns; set and lighting by Watoku Ueno; costumes by Theodora Skipitares; production manager, Virlana Tkacz; stage manager, Shigeko Suga. WITH: Estelle Parsons.   In his plays, Franz Xaver Kroetz takes the most banal of situations and transforms them into strange and haunting theatrical cameos. Slices of life become glimpses into private rituals of despair. In "Extended Forecast," an elderly widow prepares to move to a home for the aged, trying to decide which of her possessions she will take with her. This is the text of the play but not the sum of the experience. As performed by Estelle Parsons at La Mama, the monodrama is stark, simple and poignant in its details.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption on Saturday with a theater review of "Sheila's Day" misidentified the actress shown. She was Tu Nokwe.

nytimes_articles.headline: McClancy Regains Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Behind a gritty two-hitter by Mike Soto, Monsignor McClancy High School of East Elmhurst, Queens, made its third straight trip to Yankee Stadium a rousing success yesterday, winning its second Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship in three years. The score was 3-0 and the loser was St. Joseph by the Sea, a Staten Island school playing its first title game.   Soto, a senior left-hander, walked none, struck out eight and stayed cool despite three errors and a passed ball by his teammates, raising his season mark to 9-0. The victory gave McClancy a 21-4 record and dropped St. Joseph by the Sea, a former all-girls school, to 17-12. In his first year at McClancy, Soto was a member of the city championship freshman team. As a sophomore, he was on the varsity when McClancy beat Brooklyn's Xavierian at Yankee Stadium. As a junior last year, he watched the Crusaders lose the title game to Fordham Prep.

nytimes_articles.headline: WHITE HOUSE PICKS ENVOYS TO 3 LANDS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The White House plans to break the logjam that has delayed the appointment of ambassadors to several major countries, an Administration official said tonight.   Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is to be named ambassador to Japan; Richard C. Holbrooke, an investment banker who was a State Department official in the Carter Administration, is to get the post in Germany, and former Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn is to be named envoy to India.

nytimes_articles.headline: Man Questioned Without Lawyer Wins New Trial
nytimes_articles.abstract: The state's highest court ordered a new trial today for a man convicted of murder in New York City in a ruling that one judge warned could severely restrict the use of police informants.    The Court of Appeals ruled 5-to-1 that a confession by Kenneth West, taped by a police informant, should not have been admitted as trial evidence because Mr. West's lawyer was not present when he talked with the informant.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chiefs Planning to Sign Allen?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Kansas City Chiefs, who have been pursuing the free-agent running back MARCUS ALLEN, called a news conference for today amid speculation they would sign the former Los Angeles Raiders star. Allen, 33, the Raiders' career rushing leader, has running and pass-catching abilities that would fit nicely with the offense the Chiefs are installing behind newly acquired quarterback Joe Montana. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Never mind Maastricht; the new Europe, like the old, died at Sarajevo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about a trip to Florida by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, paid for by UST, a Greenwich tobacco company, referred incorrectly to an opinion that the trip violated the state ethics code. It was the personal view of the State Ethics Commission's executive director, not a draft opinion for the commission.

nytimes_articles.headline: Air Force General Faces Inquiry on Jab at Clinton
nytimes_articles.abstract: The White House today again found itself grappling with President Clinton's uneasy relations with the military, a result of reports that an Air Force two-star general made disparaging remarks about Mr. Clinton in a speech last month.    The Air Force is investigating whether the officer, Maj. Gen. Harold N. Campbell, called Mr. Clinton a "pot-smoking," "womanizing" and "draft-dodging" Commander in Chief, among other things, as some members of the audience later complained.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toward a Lasting Solution : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: As exemplified by Northern Ireland, Israel and the Gaza Strip, deeply rooted religious conflicts can last for years. Unless the antagonists in the former Yugoslavia agree on some kind of settlement, there is no outside solution possible, even with the ef

nytimes_articles.headline: Pietermaritzburg Journal; Mahatma's Vision, Now a Phoenix Fallen in Ashes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Exactly 100 years after a white conductor pitched an Indian lawyer off a train here, inadvertently launching one of history's great moral crusades, this provincial capital was a bit giddy with centennial fever this week.   In tribute to that ejected passenger, Mohandas K. Gandhi, the schools are busy with essay contests and the newspapers are filled with hindsight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reporter's Notebook; A Ceremony Both Regal and Restful
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Imperial Palace is a remarkable oasis of calm smack in the middle of Tokyo, and this morning the steady drizzle and heavy gray sky lent the overgrown grounds a romantic and secluded feeling, particularly in the thickly wooded redoubt where the wedding of Masaka Owada and Crown Prince Naruhito took place.    Although they have become the center of one of the most minutely protected monarchies in the world, the grounds are surprisingly unkempt, a wooded ramble of maple, ginko and other trees inside a moat where white swans floated silently in this morning's rain.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Woman in Command in Warsaw
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a country where women are reverentially greeted by men with a kiss on the hand, Prime Minister Hanna Suchocka has surprised most Poles, and perhaps even herself, by surviving for the last year as a popular national leader through tough economic and political times.   Her Government fell nearly two weeks ago after losing by one vote a no-confidence motion called to protest her tight budget. But Ms. Suchocka stays as Prime Minister until September elections, which she could win, and in an interview on Monday she showed in her firm yet cautious manner how a woman has succeeded in a position of power in such a male-dominated society.

nytimes_articles.headline: Housing Agency's Problems Deepen As U.S. Rescue Effort Proves Futile
nytimes_articles.abstract: A year ago, the Bush Administration announced at a news conference that it was taking control of this city's troubled public housing agency, the nation's fourth largest. The Federal officials promised to transform the agency into a model of efficiency and provide a national blueprint for rehabilitating other distressed urban housing agencies.   But the rescue mission was, by all accounts, ill conceived and a failure. And late last month the Clinton Administration quietly returned the agency's management to local authorities -- even though it was in even worse shape by many measures than it was before the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development intervened.

nytimes_articles.headline: Man Sues Company for Cost of Quitting Smoking
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Washington man says it cost him $1,153.54 to quit smoking, and he wants the Philip Morris Companies to pick up the bill.   The man, Al Deskiewicz, a 50-year-old design engineer from nearby Kirkland, told Judge Linda K. Jacke today that the tobacco company should pay for the the cost of his doctor's visits, nicotine patches and health club membership.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pity the Bosnian Muslims: so close to Allah, so far from oil.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Petrovic's Legacy: 'Pucaj Tricu'
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN the haunting hollowness of Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the basketball court was empty. The parquet floor was glossily revarnished. Its border and foul lanes had been repainted a shiny blue. But there were no baskets. No stanchions, no backboards, no orange rims, no nets.   It was as if those baskets that defined Drazen Petrovic's life were in mourning, too.

nytimes_articles.headline: PANEL URGES SHIFT IN STATION'S ORBIT
nytimes_articles.abstract: The expert panel advising the White House on redesigning the space-station has called for the proposed astronaut outpost to be launched into a "world orbit" where it could be reached not only by American space shuttles but also by Russian, Japanese and Chinese rockets.   The recommendation by the White House group for a different orbit is in a draft report to the White House that has not yet released. If kept in the final report and adopted by President Clinton, the shift would be a watershed in the history of the American space program.

nytimes_articles.headline: Costly Relic, Nuclear Unit Sits Ready for Atmospheric Tests
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the edge of the Nevada desert, and on a remote Pacific atoll, a cadre of national security sentries keeps a long, strange vigil, ready to explode a nuclear bomb in the sky.   The scientists and contractors work for Safeguard C, a program to enable the Government to resume testing nuclear weapons in the atmosphere. Thirty years after the Government forswore such tests, the Safeguard crew stays on watch, waiting for a call that never comes.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I have a proposal: If Messrs. Kouchner, Safire, Pfaff, Gelb, Lewis, Rosenthal, Rosenfeld et al are, in Marc Antony's words, "all honorable men," they should form a commando under Colonel Margaret Thatcher. This elite unit should then be dropped

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film: What's Love Got to Do With It; Tina Turner's Tale: Living Life With Ike and Then Without Him
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tina Turner, with and without Ike. Broad, savvy, entertaining.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even if the world had to put a million soldiers into Bosnia, it would be the right thing to do. I am ashamed to be English, ashamed to be European and ashamed to live in America.

nytimes_articles.headline: East Europeans Duped Into West's Sex Trade
nytimes_articles.abstract: Judith's dream to travel West, and her descent into prostitution, fell together one night in September 1991, when a car arrived to take her and two other young Hungarian women to work as waitresses in Belgium.   The heady drive across the heart of Europe took 20 hours, as planned. But the Crazy Cabaret in Ghent was no restaurant.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S.-England: A Matchup of Miseries
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States national soccer team, featuring an anemic offense and a feeble reputation, today faces a more famous opponent with an even greater level of desperation.   England not only has been disappointing recently in big matches, it also must answer to rabid supporters who really care about the sport. When the two teams meet at Foxboro Stadium in a U.S. Cup '93 match, the British team will be under severe scrutiny.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: Poison Gas Alert : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON - [From our New York edition:] President Roosevelt, taking official cognizance of reports that the Axis is preparing to use poison gas, warned the Axis armies and peoples in Europe and Asia today [June 8] that such desperate measures of warfare

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: COLLEGE BASEBALL  No. 1 A&M Eliminated  Texas A&M Coach Mark Johnson could have accepted a loss. Self-destruction is another matter. "We gave things away," Johnson said after the top-seeded Aggies were eliminated from the College World Series yesterday with a 6-2 loss to Long Beach State in Omaha. Long Beach Coach Dave Snow saw it differently: "We saw an opportunity and came up big with it." Texas, the Aggies' rival and another top team, was also eliminated, losing by 7-6 to Oklahoma State in another elimination game. In Long Beach's victory, Cobi Cradle drove in two runs in support of Daniel Choi (17-2). Cradle singled in a run in the third and another one in the seventh, sparking a four-run inning by the 49ers (45-18). For the Cowboys (45-16), Sean Hugo homered to tie the score at 6-6 in the eighth and Hunter Triplett doubled in the go-ahead run in the ninth. (AP) TENNIS  2 Seeded Stars Ousted  Goran Ivanisevic and Ivan Lendl expected to use the Queen's Club grass-court tournament as a key warmup for Wimbledon, but now they will have to get ready on the practice courts. Chris Wilkinson, a British wild-card entry ranked 176th in the world, shocked Ivanisevic, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, in one second-round match at the London tournament. Byron Black of Zimbabwe, ranked 116th, upset Lendl, 6-2, 7-6 (13-11), in another match. Among yesterday's winners were second-seeded Stefan Edberg and No. 3 Boris Becker. The fourth-seeded Ivanisevic, last year's Wimbledon finalist, fired nine aces but also had eight double faults. The fifth-seeded Lendl had a chance to level his match when he served at 5-4 in the second set but was broken. (AP) A Struggle for Navratilova: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova had to fight hard for a 7-5, 7-6 (7-1) victory over Maria Strandlund of Sweden in the second round of the Edgbaston tournament in Birmingham, England. Navratilova was kept on court for 96 minutes by the 23-year-old from Stockholm, who broke the nine-time Wimbledon champion's serve four times. (AP) Victories at the Top: Top-seeded Andrei Medvedev and second-seeded Richard Krajicek won in straight sets to advance to the second round of the Continental grass court championships in Rosmalen, the Netherlands. Medvedev, ranked eighth in the world, defeated a Dutch wild-card entry, Fernon Wibier, 6-4, 6-4. Krajicek, ranked 12th, beat Christian Saceanu of Germany, 7-6 (7-4), 6-1. Also advancing was third-seeded MaliVai Washington, a 6-4, 7-5 winner over the Dutch player, Jacco Eltingh. (AP) FENCING  New Yorker Wins Foil  Felicia Zimmermann of Rush, N.Y., last night won the national fencing championship in Division I women's foil in Fort Myers, Fla. The 17-year-old Zimmerman defeated 20-year-old Olga Chernyak of Lafayette, Calif., 6-5, 5-1, for the gold medal. Zimmermann finished fourth in this event last year. The New York Athletic Club won the men's foil team title for the ninth time in 14 years with a 9-7 victory over the Stanford Fencing Club. In the under-19 women's epee, Lauren O'Brien of Aurora, Colo., defeated Wendy Hall of Boulder, Colo., 5-2, 5-3, for the gold medal. Yvette Losman of South Orange, N.J., took the bronze. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: On April 8, the International Court of Justice in The Hague declared that the aggression by the rump Yugoslavia and Serbian nationalists against the Muslims was genocide.

nytimes_articles.headline: Freedom for Doctors
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Lest my fellow physicians get into an emotional tizzy over being controlled by the Government, I'd like to mention that somewhere in the literature is an article indicating that doctors in Europe who work for the Government usually feel freer than those working largely for themselves.   I tried private practice myself; it was a hassle. Keeping an office going, handling complicated problems alone, filling out insurance forms, isolation and worrying about fees were just a few of the problems.

nytimes_articles.headline: Long Hours Still Imperil Resident Physicians
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A May 30 article details the long days and short life of Frank Ingulli, a medical student, whose death in an automobile accident was very likely caused by exhaustion from sleep deprivation and chronic fatigue. I was chairman of the New York State Health Department committee that recommended the kinds of regulations adopted by the state to prevent such tragedies by rationalizing working conditions and supervision of resident physicians.   These recommendations were developed after 18 months of study. They were primarily to protect the public from the dangers associated with expecting sleep-deprived resident physicians to carry out their duties safely. The committee also learned that sleep deprivation and chronic fatigue were killing and maiming resident physicians and medical students who attempted to drive home after working unusually long hours.

nytimes_articles.headline: Its Schools Ruled Inadequate, Alabama Looks for Answers
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the Shiloh Elementary and Middle School here the library has not bought any books in 20 years. There are no science labs, no band, no music, no art, no foreign language courses. The roof leaks and the dingy 43-year-old building is about worn out.   There are worse schools in Alabama, like the one in adjacent Wilcox County where raw sewage seeped for years onto a playground and termites ate through books, and there are better ones. But while legislatures around the nation are struggling with questions of how to equalize spending between poor school districts and rich ones, Alabama is grappling with something even broader: a judge's ruling that its public schools violate the State Constitution by failing to provide an adequate education.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: Royal Absentee?: IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: BERLIN - The unreliability of the report that the Kaiser will attend the English Royal wedding may be gauged from the fact that His Majesty intends to both open and close the new Reichstag in person. He has made no arrangements that would cause him to mak

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Sweeney Todd' on a Small Scale
nytimes_articles.abstract: Attend the tale of Sweeney Todd: He served a dark and a hungry god. When Sondheim's bleak, black, masterly musical first opened on Broadway back in 1979 it did so in a huge Hal Prince production (seen at Drury Lane a year or so later). It is now being do

nytimes_articles.headline: Morrison on Right Side of His Dark Side
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Foreman, a stand-up comic even with swelling around his eyes, bumped his jello stomach into Tommy Morrison after their fight Monday night and whispered, "Do me a favor, never cuss on television."   In this case, it was a good tip.   Morrison is 24, keeps his gentle blond hair combed, is about to draw straws to decide if he should box Riddick Bowe or Lennox Lewis next and has a dream house and fishing rod all picked out in Grand Lake, Okla. But do not let his good looks or luck fool you. Not long ago he was considered a pathological bully with a foul mouth who, until recently, had heard only sour nothings in his ear.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON BACKS OFF PLAN FOR NEW TAX ON HEAT IN FUELS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Warned by leading Democratic senators that he was probably facing defeat, President Clinton backed away today from his proposal for a new tax based on the heat content of fuels.   Later, Democrats in the Senate met for more than two hours over lunch to try to forge a compromise that would be acceptable to the White House and could command a majority in the Senate. No consensus was reached, but senators said afterward that a different form of energy tax was still likely.

nytimes_articles.headline: Next Year's Revised S.A.T. Is Here, and Already Students (and Parents) Are Jittery
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just mention the S.A.T. and people who took the test a decade or two ago will often feel a residual pang of anxiety. So it is not surprising that future test-takers and their parents are worried about changes in the all-important standardized test.   The changes -- intended to put more emphasis on reading skills and move the examinations away from multiple-choice answers -- were announced in 1990. But next year's high school juniors will be the first to take the revised version. And it seems that the time has come to panic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nassau Proposes Schedule For Remaking Legislature
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nassau County officials today proposed a three-year timetable for the creation of a new legislative body to replace the Board of Supervisors.   Responding to a Federal judge's ruling that the weighted voting system used by the board is unconstitutional, the county said in a memorandum to Judge Arthur D. Spatt of Federal District Court that it wants a 17-member charter commission to conduct a wholesale re-evaluation of "every aspect of county government."

nytimes_articles.headline: Suns' Main Stars Off and Stumbling
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley, his jump shot oblique, frustrated even his grandmother tonight. Johnnie Mickens flew here all the way from Leeds, Ala., wished her grandson luck and then saw him dent the rim 16 times in the Phoenix Suns' loss to the Chicago Bulls in Game 1 of the championship series.   Interviewed late in the game by NBC, while a benched Barkley wore a towel on his head, Mickens said her grandson needs to rebound more fiercely and plant himself in the lane.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Music; Barber, Berlioz and a Cellist's Concerto
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York Philharmonic, hurtling toward the end of its 150th-anniversary season, reached into its scrapbook of historical connections for its program last Thursday. Victor Herbert's Second Cello Concerto and Samuel Barber's Second Essay for Orchestra had their world premieres at Philharmonic concerts in 1894 and 1942, and the orchestra gave Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique its first American performance in 1866, 36 years after its world premiere in Paris.    James DePreist conducted the orchestra with mixed but generally pleasing results. His account of the Barber, though on the brisk side, was a picture of lucidity. Details that are usually obscured -- fleeting brass effects, inner wind lines -- were spotlighted without being given an unnatural prominence. And the solo woodwind lines that weave through the essay, and also the Berlioz, were shapely and characterful and did double duty in elucidating the essay's charms and reminding listeners of one of the Philharmonic's strengths.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: It takes a measure of flexibility to cater a dinner for 1,200 people. BRIAN FINNERAN, the Waldorf-Astoria's assistant director of catering, thought everything was in order on Tuesday evening for the guests at a benefit for the One to One Partnership, an organization that provides mentors for disadvantaged youths around the country.    But then, he said yesterday: "CICELY TYSON arrived, and she had to have a baked potato. It is difficult to produce a baked potato on command, but we went back to the kitchen and rustled one up."

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-16  OIL EMBARGO PLANNED FOR HAITI  The United States and other United Nations Security Council members have decided to impose a mandatory worldwide ban on the supply of oil to Haiti as part of a new campaign to restore the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power.  A1  U.S. TO FREE HAITIANS AT BASE  The Clinton Administration announced that it would comply with a Federal court ruling ordering the release of 158 Haitian refugees, most of whom are infected with the virus that causes AIDS. They have been held at the American naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.  A12

nytimes_articles.headline: A Quest for Freedom Falls Short; Alien-Smuggling Suspect Eluded Immigration Net
nytimes_articles.abstract: Deported as an illegal alien and a felon, a man who the authorities say is a major smuggler of Chinese immigrants sneaked back into the United States, was arrested and then used a common ploy to stay in the country: He applied for political asylum.   The man, Guo Liang Chi, 27, is believed to have participated in the smuggling attempt that ended early Sunday, when a rusty freighter ran aground off the Queens shore with nearly 300 Chinese aboard. The authorities say Mr. Guo heads the Fuk Ching gang, which has forced payments from thousands of Chinese immigrants after they were brought illegally to the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: Harter Is Interested in Cavs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dick Harter, a Knicks assistant coach, said he would be interested in the Cleveland Cavaliers coaching job if contacted. Harter said he had not talked with the Cavaliers yet, but he has known Wayne Embry, the Cavaliers' general manager, for many years.    It has been reported that Cleveland is interested in speaking with Harter. Lenny Wilkens, the former Cleveland coach, resigned last month, then became the Atlanta Hawks' coach. Cotton Fitzsimmons, a longtime National Basketball Association. coach, and Paul Silas, the Nets' assistant coach, have also been mentioned as candidates in Cleveland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Burn Hackney at the Stake
nytimes_articles.abstract: The National Endowment for the Humanities suffered during the Reagan and Bush years. Prominent academics accused it of putting ideology ahead of scholarship in awarding grants. The council that advises on what scholarship, research and public programs merit Federal money grew less distinguished, with fewer good scholars and too many nonentities appointed for ideological reasons.   Sheldon Hackney, whom President Clinton is considering for the N.E.H. chairmanship, could improve this sorry record. Mr. Hackney is a distinguished historian and a past provost of Princeton.  He has been a successful president of Tulane, and now heads the University of Pennsylvania. According to Brown University's president, Vartan Gregorian, Mr. Hackney has "a judicious, moderate temperament." That's what the Endowment needs.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Connecticut, Gun Ban Just Wouldn't Die
nytimes_articles.abstract: David S. Weaver, a lobbyist from Handgun Control Inc. who marched the halls of Connecticut's Capitol preaching the virtues of a ban on the sale of assault weapons, in the end likened the issue to "a bad cough that just wouldn't go away."   Others who watched the gun bill stagger from near-defeat to near-defeat, leading up to Tuesday night's hairbreadth victory in the Senate, said the medical analogy was apt. Connecticut's law, only the third in the nation after New Jersey and California, was seen today more as a symbol of tenacity than triumph. It wouldn't go away.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Music; A Pianist Offering Sound And Silence
nytimes_articles.abstract: Danilo Perez's set at Bradley's on Monday night started out slowly, with the rhythm section clunking along, not quite finding its momentum. The second tune, "Softly as in a Morning Sunrise," changed everything, and suddenly the set took off.   Mr. Perez, a young pianist, had paired himself with the young tenor saxophonist, David Sanchez, and together they managed to articulate about every note they played. Mr. Perez played be-bop lines double-handed, as if to put them in quotes, then abruptly shifted to wispy single-note right-hand ideas, changing the density of his sound. He threw in double-handed flurries, then used silence. And his rhythmic sensibility -- funny and always surprising -- kept his improvisations moving with the suspense of a good narrative. Everything was intense: Mr. Perez had the band moving with him, building wave after wave of pressure, following his improvisations until he finished his sermon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Pop; A Subtler Sting Cuts Loose in a Smaller Hall
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's cozy in here," Sting said as he looked around the airless Paramount on Tuesday night, and for a performer who has been on the arena circuit, it probably was. Sting was smart to return to mid-size theaters like the 5,605-seat Paramount for his current tour (although he's also opening some stadium shows for the Grateful Dead), because the music he's making now moves too fast and too subtly for most arena concerts. He writes and sings pop songs, but in concert they're laced with jazzy improvisation, transforming them between the lines of catchy choruses and rolling grooves. For all of Sting's associations with causes, and the earnest moping of many of his lyrics, he has rarely been a preachy performer in concert. And on Tuesday, Sting the musician was triumphant.   While Sting's bands, including the Police, have never been content to play songs by rote, his current group takes on all challenges, from odd meters and harmonic substitutions to the openness and understatement of a ballad. Sting's own bass was both foundation and fulcrum for a nimble four-piece band including Dominic Miller on guitar, David Sancious on keyboards and Vinnie Colaiuta on drums. They don't have the jazz pedigrees of his first post-Police group, but they mesh gleefully and they know which gambits belong where.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan Is Represented by an Artist It Once Rejected
nytimes_articles.abstract: The last time Yayoi Kusama displayed her art at the Venice Biennale was 1966. Japan had refused to let her show in its official pavilion, and that was just the invitation the enfant terrible of the Japanese avant-garde needed. She crashed the prestigious event, covering the lawn with 1,500 mirrored orbs and frolicking among them in a red leotard, getting more attention than the official exhibit.   Twenty-seven years later Ms. Kusama, a small, slightly stooped rebel with dark eyes that are both soft and searing, is back. But there is a big difference this time. She has not only been invited to display her often disturbing, sexually charged works at this year's Biennale, but the exhibition will also be the first single-artist show ever mounted in the Japanese pavilion, a rare honor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suffolk Lawmakers Pass Public Financing Bill for Campaigns
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the urging of supporters of Ross Perot, the Suffolk County legislature early today passed a bill calling for public financing of county election campaigns.   If the measure is signed by the County Executive and approved in a referendum this fall, Suffolk would become the first county in the state to have public financing of campaigns. New York City and 23 states have such laws.

nytimes_articles.headline: Afternoon of Thunder: Storms Came, Soaked and Roared On
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like an errant wave, a line of thunderstorms rolled over the New York metropolitan area late yesterday afternoon, felling trees and power lines, collapsing buildings and spawning funnel-shaped clouds.    In one New Jersey county, wind gusts of 92 miles per hour were recorded. In another, all four walls of a home-fixtures store under construction were flattened. And one storm-battered town, Bound Brook, N.J., declared a state of emergency. Across the region, at least a half-dozen people were injured, most seriously.

nytimes_articles.headline: After First Game Against Suns, It's Advantage, Bulls
nytimes_articles.abstract: It took the Chicago Bulls one game to take the homecourt advantage from the Phoenix Suns.   Playing with the poise and confidence that has allowed them to win back-to-back championships, the Bulls stunned the Suns by taking a 20-point second-quarter lead. The Suns rallied, but they never caught up. Meanwhile, their best player, Charles Barkley, was harassed into a 9-of-25 shooting night, bothered by the defense of Horace Grant and Chicago's taller front line.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANGIE DICKINSON, who is accustomed to playing glamorous roles in glamorous settings, is to make an appearance today at the New York Academy of Sciences on East 63d Street for a program titled "Closing In on Alzheimer's: a Progress Report From the Lab."   She will speak to physicians, scientists and representatives of Alzheimer's and geriatric-care organizations and the National Institute on Aging, who will also hear briefings by Dr. Dennis Selkoe, professor of neurology at Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Allan Roses, professor of neurology at the Duke University Medical Center. The program is sponsored by the Dana Alliance for Brain Initiatives, an organization established in New York in November to promote research.

nytimes_articles.headline: ANDREOTTI AT CRUX OF MURDER INQUIRY
nytimes_articles.abstract: Magistrates investigating corruption in Italy asked the Senate today to permit a formal inquiry into evidence that Giulio Andreotti, Italy's master politician, ordered the murder of a journalist in 1979.    The magistrates' evidence was set out in a 90-page dossier asking the Senate to suspend Mr. Andreotti's parliamentary immunity so he can be interrogated and tried. Mr. Andreotti is already facing charges of corruption and collusion with the Mafia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Black Caucus Threatens Revolt on Clinton Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: Black Democrats in the House of Representatives today put off a meeting with President Clinton and threatened to defeat his budget package if his compromises with the Senate included retreats on Medicare, the earned income-tax credit, child hunger programs and summer jobs for youths.    It was the sharpest episode in a quarrelsome day among House Democrats, who are angry at the Senate and worried about Mr. Clinton, but not sure how much they can do about either. In frustration, they spent much of this morning fighting among themselves.

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Won't Merge Districts But Orders Review by State
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday declined to order three Bergen County school districts to merge to help achieve racial balance, but it upheld a lower-court ruling that requires the state to study the issue.   The high court's decision was significant for what it did as well as what it did not do: it chose not to rule on whether a court may order regionalization as a judicial remedy for de facto segregation. The justices also said it was unnecessary for them to decide at this point whether the State Board of Education has the authority to require regionalization.

nytimes_articles.headline: If It's Sunday, It Must Be Azinger
nytimes_articles.abstract: Paul Azinger still isn't completely over the emotions of the miracle bunker shot that won him the Memorial Tournament last Sunday, but on the eve of the first round of the Buick Classic, he could at least say that he no longer feels bad for Payne Stewart.   A few hours after Azinger had holed the 25-foot sand shot at the 72d green and gone from a stroke behind Stewart to a stroke ahead in a matter of seconds, he was still feeling melancholy about administering such a bitter defeat to his best friend on the PGA Tour. Then he opened his locker.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democracy's Doldrums
nytimes_articles.abstract: A book entitled "Giants of the Democratic World" would be exceedingly short, briefer even than "Gems of English Cookery." Nobody can recall when so many leaders have found so little public favor. Not only are incumbents of various brands unpopular. They are also generally smaller than life. Europe as a whole fits the writer Jane Kramer's description of Austria: a grand opera performed by understudies.    Bill Clinton, whose 36 percent approval rating is the lowest for any President after four months, can take cold comfort from the advice of a fellow sufferer. During a White House visit, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada urged the President to "wear unpopularity as a badge of honor." But proud defiance did not save Mr. Mulroney, who in February stepped down as party leader as his Progressive Conservatives plunged to a 21 percent approval rating, chiefly due to economic miseries.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tirana Journal; 'Hallelujah' Is Heard in the Arch-Atheist's Temple
nytimes_articles.abstract: If Enver Hoxha, Albania's dictator for more than 40 years, is turning in his monumental grave on a hillside above this capital, it would not be surprising.   On the steps of the spectacular marble-and-glass structure resembling a winged pyramid that was built to honor the man who made Albania the only country that outlawed religion, men and women who said they came from the Foursquare Gospel Church of Los Angeles were laying hands on shattered limbs, blind eyes and aching bodies the other day, and with many a "Praise the Lord!" and "Hallelujah!" prayed for healing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uncle Sam Still Wants You to Live a Lie
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Some murky descriptions of a "compromise" on lifting the military's ban on homosexuals have appeared in the news. President Clinton has referred to a plan in which, "if you don't ask and you don't say and you're not forced to confront it, people should be able to serve." The particulars of a "don't ask, don't tell," proposal, supported in its various forms by Sam Nunn, Les Aspin and Barney Frank, remain vague. What this lack of clarity likely reflects is that such plans are not fully formed. Yet the emerging compromise may also remain poorly articulated because something in its essence defies logic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Will Mr. Marino Help the Park?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Every year, it seems, Ralph Marino gets the opportunity to be a hero to millions of New York State residents who care about the environment. And every year the majority leader of the Republican-controlled Senate takes a pass. Now, in the waning days of the present legislative session, he has still another chance.   At issue is Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposal to create a permanent trust fund for land preservation, watershed protection, waste treatment and recycling. The Assembly has already approved similar legislation sponsored by Speaker Saul Weprin. If Mr. Marino tells his Senate colleagues to go along, the trust fund is certain to become law.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Close Drop-In Centers for the Homeless
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The proposed closing of homeless drop-in centers in New York City because of budget cuts is anger-provoking and saddening.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEGOTIATORS TRY TO REOPEN TALKS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations peace mediator, Lord Owen, embarked here today on another round of talks to repair a Balkan peace effort that he says has gone badly off track, threatening among other things to draw Croatia more directly into the fray.   Amid setbacks to Bosnian Croats at the hands of Muslim forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as growing tension over parts of southeastern Croatia under the control of Serbian irregulars, Lord Owen and Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway began the first of three days of meetings that will culminate in talks Saturday in Geneva between President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, a Muslim, and Mate Boban, leader of the Bosnian Croats.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. COUNCIL PLANS TO ORDER FULL BAN ON OIL FOR HAITI
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States and other United Nations Security Council members have decided to impose a mandatory worldwide ban on the supply of oil to Haiti as part of a new campaign to restore to power the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.   Plans for enforcing the blockade, which also applies to arms supplies, have not been worked out yet, diplomats said today. But the resolution imposing the ban, which is expected to be approved formally next week, will be adopted under Article 7 of the United Nations Charter, which allows the Council to enforce its orders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Refugees Blocked From Getting Legal Help
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has pledged to send a tough signal to Asian smugglers and would-be immigrants by fighting the entry of the nearly 300 Chinese refugees who washed up on a Queens beach on Sunday, is blocking legal help to them, immigrant advocate groups and lawyers say.   At the immigration service detention center at 201 Varick Street yesterday, a sign on a bulletin board near the holding cells said that until further notice, no lawyers would be permitted to visit the refugees. When a reporter asked to take a closer look, a guard, who would not identify himself, snatched the sign down.

nytimes_articles.headline: METS INSIDE PITCH
